item.title: R & Python together!
item.description: So why would you ever need to use both Python AND R? Well, they are both widely used languages which have a large array of tools with different functions. R is a programming language for statistical computing and software whereas Python is a more general-purpose coding language which can be used for a wide variety programming and development. Now, you still might be unfamiliar with Python and wondering what kind of things we can do using the language --- look no further, here is an example!

item.title: Project 1: Exploratory Data Analysis
item.description: R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. When you click the Knit button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

item.title: Project 2: Modeling, Testing, and Predicting
item.description: **0. Introduction library(dplyr) library(tidyverse) library(tidyr) library(corrplot) library(cluster) drop <- c("score", "fcollege", "mcollege", "home", "unemp","region") CollegeDistance = read.csv("filename.csv") CDistance=CollegeDistance[,!(names(CollegeDistance)%in%drop)] I have chosen a dataset which included cross-section data conducted by the Department of Education in 1980 regarding the distance of college and included high school students from 1,100 different high schools. The variables I will be analyzing are the distance (distance from a 4-year college), tuition (average state 4-year college tuition) and wage (the state hourly wage in manufacturing in 1980).
